question: Which of the following is true about degenerative myopia?
correct_answer: Myopic degeneration can lead to retinal detachment
options: A)More common in males as compared to females
B)Myopic degeneration can lead to retinal detachment
C)It is seen in less than 6 dioptres of myopia.
D)The condition has no racial prediliction.
prompt:
Which of the following is true about degenerative myopia?A)More common in males as compared to females
B)Myopic degeneration can lead to retinal detachment
C)It is seen in less than 6 dioptres of myopia.
D)The condition has no racial prediliction.
output0: Degenerative myopia is more common in males than in females. This is because males tend to have more myopia and are more likely to develop complications such as retinal detachment.
output1: Myopic degeneration, which is also known as degenerative myopia, is a condition that can lead to retinal detachment. This is because the elongation of the eye that occurs with myopia can put strain on the retina, leading to tears or holes in the retina that can cause vision loss.
output2: Degenerative myopia is a condition where the retina degenerates and becomes thinner over time, leading to vision loss. It is more common in people with high levels of myopia (nearsightedness), and is often seen in those with more than 6 dioptres of myopia.
output3: Degenerative myopia is a condition that affects the retina and can lead to vision loss, but it does not have a racial prediliction. It can affect anyone regardless of their race or ethnicity.

question: Ismael, after suffering a hip fracture, is subjected to a hip hemiarthroplasty. Which of the following postural norms will be indicated to teach Ismael during his hospital stay:
correct_answer: When Ismael is going to get out of bed he will do it on the side of the operated extremity in order to avoid internal rotation.
options: A)In the bed you should stay with your legs as close together as possible and without rotating your feet externally.
B)When Ismael is going to get out of bed he will do it on the side of the operated extremity in order to avoid internal rotation.
C)If Ishmael sits in an armchair, the height of the chair should allow the hip to be lower than the knees.
D)When it is necessary to lateralize Ismael for hygiene or change of bedding this will be placed on the operated side.
prompt:
Ismael, after suffering a hip fracture, is subjected to a hip hemiarthroplasty. Which of the following postural norms will be indicated to teach Ismael during his hospital stay:A)In the bed you should stay with your legs as close together as possible and without rotating your feet externally.
B)When Ismael is going to get out of bed he will do it on the side of the operated extremity in order to avoid internal rotation.
C)If Ishmael sits in an armchair, the height of the chair should allow the hip to be lower than the knees.
D)When it is necessary to lateralize Ismael for hygiene or change of bedding this will be placed on the operated side.
output0: The postural norms indicated for Ismael during his hospital stay are aimed at avoiding any movement or position that may cause discomfort or exacerbate the injury. The norm A) is the most appropriate, as it helps to maintain the alignment of the operated hip and prevent any external rotation of the legs.
output1: When a patient has undergone a hip hemiarthroplasty, it is important to avoid internal rotation of the affected limb to prevent dislocation of the prosthesis. Therefore, it is recommended that the patient get out of bed on the side of the operated extremity, as it will help to avoid internal rotation and prevent complications.
output2: This postural norm is indicated to help Ismael avoid excessive external rotation of the hip, which can lead to discomfort or even injury. By sitting in an armchair with the hip lower than the knees, Ismael will be able to maintain a more neutral posture and avoid putting excessive pressure on the operated hip.
output3: The correct answer is D)When it is necessary to lateralize Ismael for hygiene or change of bedding this will be placed on the operated side. This is indicated because the operated side should be kept as immobile as possible to avoid any external rotation or movement that could disrupt the healing process.

question: Question linked to image no.31 A 26-year-old woman consulted for a fever of 3 weeks evolution. The fever was daily, in peaks that reached 38.5 ° C and sometimes at 39 ° C, and was accompanied by pharyngeal pain, myalgias and arthralgias of large joints. Within a few hours the fever subsided spontaneously or by some antipyretic. During the febrile episodes it presented a rash. The patient reported that she had presented two previous episodes in the previous two years, very similar to the current one, which had not been diagnosed despite in-depth studies. He had not made trips outside of Spain nor did he refer epidemiological antecedents of interest. The clinical examination during a febrile episode showed the skin rash that can be seen in the image, which disappeared in a few hours. The patient also had pharyngeal hyperemia, bilateral small painful laterocervical lymphadenopathies and a spleen pole was palpated below the left costal arch. To establish the diagnosis, it is expected that several laboratory and imaging studies should be performed. However, which of the following statements seems more appropriate in the current diagnostic phase?
correct_answer: Although it is a diagnosis of exclusion, I would request a serum ferritin because of the possibility that it is an adult Still's disease.
options: A)It would request serological tests for hepatitis B and C, human parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus and test for the human immunodeficiency virus, since the most likely cause are infectious diseases, especially acute viral infections.
B)Although it is a diagnosis of exclusion, I would request a serum ferritin because of the possibility that it is an adult Still's disease.

C)It would request an immunological study that included antinuclear antibodies, rheumatoid factor, citrullinated cyclic antiseptide antibodies and ANCAs to confirm the suspicion of a systemic rheumatic disease such as rheumatoid arthritis or systemic lupus erythematosus.
D)I would request a genetic study given that it is most likely a familial Mediterranean fever type autoinflammatory disease.
prompt:
Question linked to image no.31 A 26-year-old woman consulted for a fever of 3 weeks evolution. The fever was daily, in peaks that reached 38.5 ° C and sometimes at 39 ° C, and was accompanied by pharyngeal pain, myalgias and arthralgias of large joints. Within a few hours the fever subsided spontaneously or by some antipyretic. During the febrile episodes it presented a rash. The patient reported that she had presented two previous episodes in the previous two years, very similar to the current one, which had not been diagnosed despite in-depth studies. He had not made trips outside of Spain nor did he refer epidemiological antecedents of interest. The clinical examination during a febrile episode showed the skin rash that can be seen in the image, which disappeared in a few hours. The patient also had pharyngeal hyperemia, bilateral small painful laterocervical lymphadenopathies and a spleen pole was palpated below the left costal arch. To establish the diagnosis, it is expected that several laboratory and imaging studies should be performed. However, which of the following statements seems more appropriate in the current diagnostic phase?A)It would request serological tests for hepatitis B and C, human parvovirus B19, Epstein-Barr virus and test for the human immunodeficiency virus, since the most likely cause are infectious diseases, especially acute viral infections.
B)Although it is a diagnosis of exclusion, I would request a serum ferritin because of the possibility that it is an adult Still's disease.
C)It would request an immunological study that included antinuclear antibodies, rheumatoid factor, citrullinated cyclic antiseptide antibodies and ANCAs to confirm the suspicion of a systemic rheumatic disease such as rheumatoid arthritis or systemic lupus erythematosus.
D)I would request a genetic study given that it is most likely a familial Mediterranean fever type autoinflammatory disease.
output0: The most likely diagnosis for this patient is an acute viral infection, such as parvovirus B19 or Epstein-Barr virus, given the clinical picture of fever, pharyngeal pain, myalgias, and arthralgias, as well as the rash that disappears in a few hours. Therefore, serological tests for these viruses would be the most appropriate diagnostic test at this time.
output1: The patient's symptoms, such as recurrent fever, pharyngeal pain, myalgias, and arthralgias, are consistent with adult Still's disease. Additionally, the presence of a rash and the patient's history of two previous similar episodes suggest that the condition may be autoinflammatory in nature. While other infectious and rheumatic diseases should also be considered, a serum ferritin test is a useful tool for ruling out adult Still's disease as a possible diagnosis.
output2: The patient's history of recurrent fever episodes, accompanied by pharyngeal pain, myalgias, and arthralgias, as well as the presence of a rash, suggest a systemic rheumatic disease such as rheumatoid arthritis or systemic lupus erythematosus. The patient's age and the absence of other causes of fever suggest that an immunological study would be appropriate to confirm the diagnosis.
output3: The patient's symptoms, such as recurrent fever, rash, and joint pain, are consistent with a familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) type autoinflammatory disease. The patient's history of two previous episodes in the past two years, without a clear diagnosis, also supports this diagnosis. Additionally, the patient's symptoms and signs, such as pharyngeal hyperemia, bilateral small painful laterocervical lymphadenopathies, and a spleen pole, are consistent with FMF. Therefore, a genetic study would be the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm the diagnosis.

question: A 27-year primigravida presents with PIH with BP of 150/100 mm of Hg at 32 weeks of gestation.If there are no complications, the pregnancy should be best terminatedat:
options: A)40 completed weeks
B)37 completed weeks
C)35 completed weeks.
D)34 completed weeks.
prompt:
A 27-year primigravida presents with PIH with BP of 150/100 mm of Hg at 32 weeks of gestation.If there are no complications, the pregnancy should be best terminatedat:A)40 completed weeks
B)37 completed weeks
C)35 completed weeks.
D)34 completed weeks.
output0: The correct answer is A)40 completed weeks. In cases of pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH) with a blood pressure of 150/100 mm of Hg at 32 weeks of gestation, the pregnancy should be terminated at 40 completed weeks to reduce the risk of complications such as placental abruption or fetal growth restriction.
output1: The recommended gestational age for termination of pregnancy in cases of severe preeclampsia with BP of 150/100 mm of Hg is 37 completed weeks. This is because preeclampsia can rapidly worsen and become life-threatening for both the mother and the baby after 37 weeks of gestation.
output2: The pregnancy should be terminated at 35 completed weeks because the risk of complications increases after 35 weeks of gestation. In this case, the patient is at 32 weeks of gestation, which is considered a high-risk pregnancy.
output3: The Turtle Technique is primarily indicated for older children, specifically those in the last courses of Primary Education. This approach is often used to help children in this age group develop better self-control and emotional regulation skills.

question: After I.V. administration of which of the following anesthetic agent, there is rapid recovery and less headedness?
options: A)Propofol
B)Diazepam
C)Droperidol
D)Midazolam
prompt:
After I.V. administration of which of the following anesthetic agent, there is rapid recovery and less headedness?A)Propofol
B)Diazepam
C)Droperidol
D)Midazolam
output0: Propofol is an anesthetic agent that is known for its rapid onset and recovery times, as well as its ability to cause less drowsiness or "headedness" compared to other anesthetic agents.
output1: Diazepam is a benzodiazepine that is commonly used for sedation in children. It has a rapid onset of action and a short duration of effect, which results in rapid recovery and less drowsiness compared to other anesthetic agents.
output2: Droperidol is a short-acting anesthetic agent that is commonly used for sedation and anxiolysis in children. It has a rapid onset of action and a short duration of effect, which results in rapid recovery and less drowsiness compared to other anesthetic agents.
output3: Midazolam is an anesthetic agent that is known for its rapid recovery time and minimal sedation. It is often used in children and adults for procedures that require only light sedation, such as endoscopies and colonoscopies.

question: The hair cells of the semicircular canals:
correct_answer: They are depolarized by K + entry from the endolymph.
options: A)They detect linear acceleration.
B)They are depolarized by K + entry from the endolymph.
C)They have otoliths on their surface.
D)They orientate their stereocilia perpendicular to the striola.
prompt:
The hair cells of the semicircular canals:A)They detect linear acceleration.
B)They are depolarized by K + entry from the endolymph.
C)They have otoliths on their surface.
D)They orientate their stereocilia perpendicular to the striola.
output0: The hair cells of the semicircular canals detect linear acceleration, which is essential for maintaining balance and equilibrium. They are depolarized by K + entry from the endolymph, which is the fluid that fills the inner ear. The hair cells have otoliths on their surface, which are small structures that detect the movement of the head and help the hair cells to detect linear acceleration. Finally, the stereocilia of the hair cells are oriented perpendicular to the striola, which is the small channel that runs along the length of the semicircular canal.
output1: The hair cells of the semicircular canals are depolarized by K + entry from the endolymph, which is the fluid that fills the inner ear. This depolarization causes the hair cells to fire and send signals to the brain about the direction and magnitude of linear acceleration.
output2: The hair cells of the semicircular canals have otoliths on their surface, which are small calcium carbonate crystals that move in response to changes in head position and linear acceleration. This movement causes the hair cells to depolarize, sending signals to the brain about the direction and speed of the movement.
output3: The hair cells of the semicircular canals orientate their stereocilia perpendicular to the striola. This allows the hair cells to detect angular acceleration, which is essential for maintaining balance and orientation.

question: From the previous question, the disposal of the patient in the emergency room, which of the following is most appropriate?
correct_answer: Urine osmolality measurement, and given 0.9% NaCl
options: A)Brain computer tomography, and give oral kayexalate 60 mg
B)Urine osmolality measurement, and given 0.9% NaCl
C)Arterial blood gas analysis, and for bacterial culture of blood
D)Cerebro-spinal fluid, and given 5% glucose solution, 5 units of short-acting insulin
prompt:
From the previous question, the disposal of the patient in the emergency room, which of the following is most appropriate?A)Brain computer tomography, and give oral kayexalate 60 mg
B)Urine osmolality measurement, and given 0.9% NaCl
C)Arterial blood gas analysis, and for bacterial culture of blood
D)Cerebro-spinal fluid, and given 5% glucose solution, 5 units of short-acting insulin
output0: The most appropriate disposal of the patient in the emergency room with the described symptoms is a Brain Computer Tomography (BCT) scan, followed by oral Kayexalate 60 mg. This approach is recommended because it can help identify the presence of an acute subdural hematoma, which is a common complication of traumatic brain injury. Additionally, the oral Kayexalate can help reduce the risk of further bleeding in the brain.
output1: The correct answer is B)Urine osmolality measurement, and given 0.9% NaCl. This is the most appropriate option for the disposal of the patient in the emergency room, as it will help to determine the severity of the condition and the appropriate treatment.
output2: The correct answer is C)Arterial blood gas analysis, and for bacterial culture of blood. This is the most appropriate approach for evaluating the patient's respiratory and metabolic status, as well as for detecting any signs of infection.
output3: The correct answer is D)Cerebro-spinal fluid, and given 5% glucose solution, 5 units of short-acting insulin because it is the most appropriate approach for a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) who has been admitted to the emergency room.

question: The thermodynamic magnitude that allows to determine if a closed system at constant temperature and pressure, able to perform only P-V work, is in equilibrium is:
correct_answer: The Gibbs free energy of the system.
options: A)The internal energy of the system.
B)The Gibbs free energy of the system.
C)The Helmholtz free energy of the system.
D)The number of moles of the system.
prompt:
The thermodynamic magnitude that allows to determine if a closed system at constant temperature and pressure, able to perform only P-V work, is in equilibrium is:A)The internal energy of the system.
B)The Gibbs free energy of the system.
C)The Helmholtz free energy of the system.
D)The number of moles of the system.
output0: The internal energy of the system (U) is a thermodynamic magnitude that can be used to determine if a closed system at constant temperature and pressure is in equilibrium. If the internal energy of the system is constant, it means that the system is in equilibrium and no work is being done on the system.
output1: The Gibbs free energy of a system is a measure of the maximum amount of energy that can be obtained from the system at constant temperature and pressure. When the system is in equilibrium, the Gibbs free energy of the system is at its minimum value, indicating that the system is in a state of maximum entropy.
output2: The Helmholtz free energy of a system is the thermodynamic magnitude that allows us to determine if a closed system at constant temperature and pressure is in equilibrium. It is defined as the sum of the internal energy of the system and the product of the volume of the system and the pressure.
output3: The number of moles of the system is not a thermodynamic property that can determine if a closed system is in equilibrium. The correct answer is D)The number of moles of the system.

question: The significance of free eugenol in root canal sealer-cements is an increase in:
options: A)Dimensional stability
B)Setting time
C)Cytotoxicity
D)Strength
prompt:
The significance of free eugenol in root canal sealer-cements is an increase in:A)Dimensional stability
B)Setting time
C)Cytotoxicity
D)Strength
output0: The presence of free eugenol in root canal sealer-cements can increase the dimensional stability of the material, which is important for maintaining the shape and integrity of the tooth.
output1: The presence of free eugenol in root canal sealer-cements increases the setting time of the material. This is because eugenol acts as a catalyst, accelerating the polymerization of the sealer-cement.
output2: The presence of free eugenol in root canal sealer-cements can increase the cytotoxicity of the material. Eugenol is a component of clove oil and is known to have antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory properties, but it can also be toxic to cells in high concentrations. Therefore, the amount of free eugenol in the sealer-cement is important to consider to ensure the safety of the patient.
output3: The presence of free eugenol in root canal sealer-cements has been found to increase the strength of the final restoration. Eugenol is a natural antimicrobial agent that can help to prevent bacterial growth and improve the overall durability of the restoration.
